document.docTitle: Parahyadina edmistoni Mathis & Zatwarnicki 2019, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Revision of the Shore-fly Genera Parahyadina Tonnoir and Malloch and New Zealand Hyadina Haliday (Diptera: Ephydridae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Revision of the Shore-fly Genera Parahyadina Tonnoir and Malloch and New Zealand Hyadina Haliday (Diptera: Ephydridae)

subSubSection.paragraph: Diagnosis. This species is distinguished from congeners by the following combination of characters: Adults. Small to moderately small shore flies, body length 1.40–2.20 mm .

Head ( Fig. 28 ): Lateroclinate fronto-orbital seta evident but variable, weakly or well developed, if well developed then basal diameter comparable or only slightly reduced in comparison to basal diameters of lateral vertical setae.

Thorax ( Fig. 28 ): 2 pairs of posterior dorsocentral setae, anterior seta shorter than posterior seta. Wing hyaline; costal section II about equal in length to costal section III; costal vein ratio 0.95–1.05; M vein ratio 0.24–0.39

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 33–36.
Parahyadina edmistoni
sp. nov.
(male; New Zealand. North Island. ND, Hailes Road (quarry)). 33. Epandrium, cerci, and surstyli, posterior view. 34. Same, lateral view. 35. Internal structures of male terminalia, ventral view. 36. Same, lateral view (scale bar = 0.1 mm).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type Specimen. The holotype male is labeled “ New Zealand . N[orth] I[sland], ND, Hailes Road, quarry 37°[]sic, should be 35°] 31.1’S, 174°25.8’E [,] 19 February 1998 , V. Hollmann-Schirmacher/ USNM ENT 00250355 [plastic bar code label]/ HOLOTYPE ♂
Parahyadina edmistoni Mathis & Zatwarnicki
NZAC [red].” The holotype is double mounted (minuten in a plastic block), is in excellent condition, and is deposited in the NZAC . Ten paratypes ( 6♂ , 4♀ ; USNM ) bear the same label data as the holotype except for some ( 4♂ , 3♀ ), W. N. Mathis was the collector.

New Zealand .
North Island. ND
, Hailes Road (quarry 35°31.1’S , 174°25.8’E )
.

Distribution ( Map 7 ). Australasian/Oceanian: New Zealand . North Island (AK, BP, ND, TO), South Island (MC, MK, NN, OL).

Etymology. The species epithet,
edmistoni ,
is a genitive Latin patronym to honor Father James F. Edmiston, O. F. M., Ph.D., a former colleague in the study of shore flies and a personal friend. Jim passed away on Sunday, May 18, 2008 (born 18 July 1954 ), and is still greatly missed. Before his untimely death, Jim had intended to participate in this study, primarily in adding a molecular analysis of the included species.

Remarks. Like specimens of
H. breva ,
the lateroclinate fronto-orbital seta is weakly developed, in some specimens almost setula-like.Also like
H. breva ,
the structures of the male terminalia are unique ( Figs. 33–36 ) and unlike the pattern for most congeners. The surstyli, for example, are robustly developed, elongated, mostly parallel sided, and are shallowly curved medially. The surstylar apex is also obliquely truncated and not acute. The keel of the phallapodeme ( Fig. 36 ) is also elongated and in lateral view appears rectangular in shape.
